description:
Cnephaeus nilssonii is a species of beetle belonging to the family Staphylinidae, commonly known as rove beetles. It is a small insect, typically measuring around 3-5 millimeters in length.

Cnephaeus nilssonii is found in parts of Europe, including Sweden, Norway, and Finland. The species is typically found in forested habitats, where it lives in the soil and leaf litter, feeding on decaying organic matter and small invertebrates.

The beetle's body is elongated and slender, with a distinct head and thorax. Its coloration is generally dark, ranging from reddish-brown to black. The species has a distinctive set of antennae and legs, which it uses for locomotion and sensory perception.

Cnephaeus nilssonii is an important component of the forest ecosystem, contributing to the decomposition of organic matter and playing a role in the nutrient cycling of the environment. The species is considered relatively common within its geographic range, but its population status and conservation needs may vary depending on local habitat conditions and environmental factors.
